data.title: Tranquility in the Presence of Others (1972)
data.meta_description: A colonel, who has two daughters working as nurses in Tehran, retires to a small city. The man marries a teacher from the provinces and goes with her to Tehran. However, he finds that his daughters have changed. The elder daughter eventually commits suicide and the younger daughter goes through an ill-fated marriage. The father, observing the problems of his children, goes insane and is confined to an asylum. For its political and social content, the film was banned by the government for several years.
data.text:
Closer in spirit to Brick and Mirror than any of the other films playing in the Iranian New Wave strand; focusing in on the contradictions and rot that is settling in on the upper middle classes in Tehran. It’s a choppy and disquieting film, but how much of that is due to the degraded copy we were watching?

From an interview with Ehsan Khoshbakht:

“So, the idea of preserving the history of Iranian cinema is another major concern of mine on a daily basis. How can more films be made accessible? How can films be made accessible in decent-to-ideal copies? You have seen the entire range of that in this MoMA show, from absolutely fantastic, first-rate restorations of films to copies…

Alienation in a bourgeois family in pre-revolution Iran. Crawls under one's skin in very strange manner - on the surface it's mostly a melodrama but there's real sense of tragedy there. And at the same time those last moments are truly mesmerizing and ambiguous, giving the film a new meaning, kind of condensing its mysterious undertone. Locations have strong presence as do human faces; the villa in which the family resides, its surrounding alleys as well as the mental hospital all seem to hide secrets, both have threatening as well as deeply sad atmosphere. I'm missing historical and social context for more detailed analysis but the film feels like an attempt at overall view or characterization of the state of…

I can understand why this was included in the pre-revolutionary Iranian cinema retrospective, as it's the kind of thing that you can imagine was primed to be banned and subsequently forgotten, dealing as it does with an elderly father whose daughters have moved to the city and have taken paths that aren't what he wants. These cause them a fair amount of turmoil in their lives and when the father arrives to check up on them, the whirlwind of emotions eventually pushes him into a hospital.
